node.text: In a bid to chip away at the remaining hesitancy regarding makeup on men, we asked the makeup artist @RaisaFlowers to do a pair of video tutorials demonstrating looks that readers can, she hopes, easily replicate at home. In the one shown here, she realizes a look inspired by the 1998 film “Velvet Goldmine,” with shimmery purple eye shadow and translucent tinted lip balm. The overall effect is meant to be one of high-impact minimalism tempered with subtle playfulness. Visit tmagazine.com for more. Video by Justin French (@frenchgold), styled by @YohanaLebasi. #TBeautyIssue

node.title: Makeup for Men, or Anyone: Full-Face Glam

node.text: As part of T’s Beauty & Luxury issue, the writer @MeganEOGrady explores what makeup means to the growing group of men who have embraced it. Her piece is accompanied by photos of models with faces done by the makeup artist @RaisaFlowers, who, in a bid to make such adornment less intimidating, breaks down her process in a pair of video tutorials, demonstrating what she calls two “simplistic and masculine” looks that readers can, she hopes, easily replicate at home. In one video, she shares tips for creating dewy skin accented with a vivid swipe of color across the lids, and in another, she realizes a more classically glamorous visage with shimmery purple eye shadow and translucent tinted lip balm. The overall effect of both styles is a kind of high-impact minimalism tempered with subtle playfulness. See more on tmagazine.com. Video by Justin French (@frenchgold), styled by @YohanaLebasi. #TBeautyIssue

node.title: Minimal Makeup Looks for Men — or Anyone

node.text: A brief history of how New York’s Sag Harbor became a refuge for African-American families, with testimonials from some of the residents who’ve summered there for much of their lives. Read Sandra E. Garcia's (@s_evangelina) accompanying story on this close-knit community on tmagazine.com. Video by @JoshuaKissi. Produced by Tom Delavan (@tdelavan).

node.title: Long Island's Enduring Black Beachfront Community

node.text: Flip your phone horizontally to watch this video: On Feb. 25 and 26, 2020, T gathered seven established black actresses — all of whom got their start decades ago, working across various mediums — for a group and cover shoot by the photographers @MickaleneThomas and @RacquelChevremont in Los Angeles, California. In it, these women — @HalleBerry, Angela Bassett (@im.angelabassett), @TarajiPHenson, Mary J. Blige (@therealmaryjblige), Lynn Whitfield (@mslynnwhitfield), @ViolaDavis and Kimberly Elise (@ikimberlyelise) — remember their first roles and discuss the solidarity they feel with one another. “We are living in an age in which some of our greatest, most successful actors are black women, near 50 or older, veterans who have fought against an industry that for much of its history would have rather ignored them,” writes @BrianKeithJackson in the accompanying story. Read more on Tmagazine.com. Video by @scottrossfilm.

node.text: Flip your phone horizontally to watch this video: On Oct. 15, 2018, T gathered 32 black American male poets, playwrights and novelists — writers whose work is so crucial to our understanding America itself — at the Brooklyn Historical Society for a group portrait creative directed by @BootsRiley and this accompanying short film by @YvonneMichelleShirley. In it, these men reflect on their experiences and quote from some of their favorite works by black female American writers, whose voices are equally powerful and necessary. As Audre Lorde once said, “We don't only write about ourselves, we use ourselves to illuminate something that we really believe and we really feel.” Read the accompanying story, and why we chose to focus specifically on black men for this piece, on Tmagazine.com. You’ll also find a reading list chosen by these men of their favorite black female writers.

node.title: On Being a Black Male Writer in America

node.text: Around the country, restaurants are expanding their menus of thoughtful, complex, nonalcoholic cocktails to keep pace — especially this month — with a population that’s drinking less. And while these drinks are made for adult palates, they’re also drawing an unexpected fan base: children. T hosted a taste test, inviting children of the magazine’s staff and writers to assess several mocktails at @ReceptionBar.NYC, a modern Korean spot on Manhattan’s Lower East Side. Video by @scottrossfilm.

node.text: Block Shop Textiles printer Mukesh Chhipa works on a paper block print in the village of Bagru.

node.title: Ancient Art of Block Printing in Jaipur

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by T: The NYTimes Style Magazine on July 29, 2021. May be art of furniture and living room.

node.text: #RoomOfTheDay: Carlo Scarpa's reimagining of ancient public buildings made him an Italian icon, but the 20th-century architect is perhaps best understood through the private homes he designed. In the garden room at the Zentner House, built in the 1960s in Zurich, two ’70s-era paintings by Piero Dorazio hang over a LC4 chaise by Le Corbusier, Pierre Jeanneret and Charlotte Perriand. Photo by @IlariaOrsini.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by T: The NYTimes Style Magazine on July 29, 2021 tagging @daylesfordfarm, and @carolebamford. May be an image of flower.

node.text: When she lived in Staffordshire in the mid-1970s, @CaroleBamford, the founder of the pioneering British brand Daylesford Organic (@daylesfordfarm), and her friends would make a pilgrimage each spring to the Chelsea Flower Show in London. “I would always gravitate toward the geranium stand,” she recalls. For Bamford, the plants possessed an intriguing, almost paradoxical power: Their blossoms were delicate and modest, but their homely, almost cabbagelike leaves had an entrancing and deeply robust scent. In fact, geraniums and their fragrances have been a lifelong fascination for her, and anchor her range of bath and body products, which she launched in 2005 and has integrated into the treatments at her namesake chain of holistic spas. They’re also the stars of the garden of her and her husband’s estate, where she grows more than 120 geranium (technically, pelargonium) species, from Attar of Roses, a variety with narrow, daisylike petals in a pale, icy pink and deep cerise-colored stamens, to Tomentosum, which has large, downy peppermint-smelling leaves and tiny white flowers. Pictured here are a Margaret Soley and, on the second slide, a red Jako. Click the link in our bio to go inside Bamford's greenhouse. Written by Sophie Bew (@sophie_bew), photos by Michael Vince Kim.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by T: The NYTimes Style Magazine on July 29, 2021 tagging @daylesfordfarm, and @carolebamford. May be an image of flower.
Photo by T: The NYTimes Style Magazine on July 29, 2021. May be an image of flower.
Photo by T: The NYTimes Style Magazine on July 29, 2021. May be art of 2 people, people standing and indoor.

node.text: Leigh Batnick Plessner, the co-creative director of Catbird, Brooklyn’s destination for fine jewelry, slid into the artist Cassi Namoda’s DMs back in September. A fan of Namoda’s paintings, Plessner wanted to gift her a piece from Catbird’s collaboration with the Met. Namoda, it turned out, has long been fascinated with the history of jewelry; her personal collection ranges from an Ethiopian bronze bracelet to a Hellenistic necklace with Carnelian. The two soon decided to create a capsule collection of their own. The seven-piece line was inspired by Namoda’s home country, Mozambique, and the real-life hidden treasures on sunken merchant ships unearthed by locals on deep dive expeditions. “My cousin, who lives there, has the most beautiful collection from these excursions,” says the artist. Among the designs is an aquamarine choker and a matching garnet-and-pearl necklace and earring set inspired by Princess Elizabeth of Toro, an accomplished lawyer, politician and diplomat, who is one of Namoda’s muses. Written by Angela Koh. #TList

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by T: The NYTimes Style Magazine on July 29, 2021 tagging @ladyandlarder. May be an image of fruit.

node.text: Throughout the pandemic, restaurants have adapted their offerings and worked out which sandwiches wrap up best (sorry, sloppy Joes) and which cocktails translate well in to-go containers (it turns out there’s no bad receptacle for a margarita). And so we are living, it seems, in the golden age of the picnic. @LadyandLarder in Mar Vista, co-owned by the sisters Sarah Simms Hendrix and Boo Simms, sells almost rococo cheese and charcuterie boards — imagine a kaleidoscopic array of crudités circling homemade dips and dressed up with flowers and herbs — for both pickup and delivery. Any one of these creations would make for a dramatic picnic centerpiece, whether you’re hosting in your backyard or at the beach. Click the link in our bio for a list of restaurants across the country that are offering park-friendly fare, as well as recommendations for colorful rugs and durable dinnerware to eat it on, and a pair of recipes to try if you feel like playing chef for the day. Written by Marian Bull (@mariantoro). #TSummerEntertaining

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by T: The NYTimes Style Magazine on July 28, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, standing and outdoors.

node.text: For her newest show, “Fragile Concrete,” the Slovak photographer Mária Švarbová (@maria.svarbova) captured a young, fashionable couple posing throughout the Le Corbusier-designed Cité Radieuse, a Brutalist apartment building in France’s Marseille, where her exhibition is also on view. The pair, often shot in relaxed yet playful positions, appear almost as deities in the complex’s various terraces and alcoves. In “Cariatide and Atlante” (2021), the woman stands behind the man, clutching him as he raises his hands toward the rooftop, as if supporting the weight of the structure all on his own. “Helénê and Pâris” (2021) and “Apollon and Daphnée” (2021) depict a far less impassioned couple, each turned away from the other, barely touching, absorbed instead by the sublime vastness of their surroundings. In all of the 19 images, the subjects’ gestures are delicate and subtle, intensified only by the richness of the colors around them: the Radieuse’s white concrete slabs, the bright azure of the Mediterranean sky and shore. Written by Eric Morse. © Mária Švarbová for Kolektiv Cité Radieuse, with authorization from Le Corbusier Foundation ©FLC/ADAGP Paris 2021. #TList

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by T: The NYTimes Style Magazine on July 28, 2021. May be an image of furniture and bedroom.

node.text: #RoomOfTheDay: The interior designer @NicoloCastelliniBaldissera used some of his extra time during the pandemic to transform his Milan home into an idiosyncratic bohemian retreat. In a bedroom, a crystal chandelier from Castellini Baldissera’s maternal grandmother hangs over an 18th-century Genovese wrought-iron bed. The trompe l’oeil walls were painted by Pictalab. Photo by Guido Taroni (@guidotaroniphotographer).

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by T: The NYTimes Style Magazine on July 27, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and food.

node.text: Benoît Rauzy and Anthony Watson — who together founded @AtelierVime, a line of handcrafted Provençal wicker furniture, decorative accessories and antiques in 2014 — recently celebrated a long-awaited reunion with friends with a lunch at their home in the French countryside. The focal point of the menu was a take on Île de Sein soup. A well-loved lobster dish that was traditionally made by sailors’ wives, it’s named after the one-mile-long strip of nearby land that’s famed for its indomitable fishermen. “It was made by Bruno Fouquet, a family friend from the village,” said Watson. “He’s the only one left who knows this very special version of the dish, which is an old family recipe.” Along with generous helpings of Homard Breton lobster, Fouquet’s blend features potatoes, onion and a secret mix of herbs including saffron. His take also comes with one unique addition — a generous splash of whiskey. “It adds real bite,” said Watson. Click the link in our bio for Rauzy and Watson’s guide to hosting a relaxed Breton-style lunch of your own. Written by Aimee Farrell (@aimee_farrell), photo by Roland Beaufre (@roland_beaufre). #TSummerEntertaining

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by T: The NYTimes Style Magazine on July 27, 2021 tagging @carnemare. May be an image of dessert and indoor.

node.text: The only steak carved tableside at @CarneMare, chef @AndrewCarmellini’s new chophouse in New York’s revitalized South Street Seaport, is made not of beef but of beet — a regular red one, on the larger side, which evokes the pageantry, texture and taste of the menu’s meatier options (albeit with a bit of “cheekiness,” as Carmellini notes) thanks to its clever preparation. Kept whole, each beet is brined, then dry-rubbed with a mixture of spices, charred onion and dehydrated vegetables — which lends it umami and mimics a steak’s seared crust — before being smoked, slow-roasted, then basted in a pan with butter, garlic, thyme and rosemary. “Vegetarianism is part of modern, urban life,” says Carmellini, who was inspired by his wife, a former vegetarian, to create the dish. “And this allows people to participate in the [chophouse] culture and not have a piece of meat.” Click the link in our bio for more. Written by @KurtSoller, photo by Briana Balducci. #TList

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by T: The NYTimes Style Magazine on July 27, 2021. May be an image of indoor.

node.text: #RoomOfTheDay: A former hunting camp, Kate and Bob Horgna’s home on a tiny Maine island is at the mercy of the open Atlantic, which also affords breathtaking views. In the property’s guest house, pictured here, doors span almost the entirety of the ocean-side wall, allowing the bedroom to double as a luxurious lean-to. From the book “The Maine House” (@themainehouse_thebook), which has photography by @MauraMcEvoy, art direction by Basha Burwell (@basha_oog) and words by @KathleenHackett, and is out now from @vendomepress.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by T: The NYTimes Style Magazine on July 26, 2021. May be an image of food and indoor.

node.text: Shing Tat Chung and Erchen Chang, the husband-and-wife duo behind London’s beloved Bao restaurants (@bao_london), as well as Xu Teahouse & Restaurant (@xu_london), met while studying at the Slade School of Fine Art, which perhaps explains their proclivity for food with flair. Each restaurant or event that the couple do is an extension of their artistic practices, and the private dinners they throw at their Victorian terraced home in Forest Gate in East London are just as considered. Earlier this month, they invited four close friends over for an intimate gathering. On the table were squishy-looking bao-shaped candles designed by Chang, along with a set of hand-painted Kraak dishes that are near-exact copies of Ming and Qing period Chinese designs, rustic scallop shells that were used as dipping bowls, dark wooden chopsticks and, in the center, a raised dish filled with pork and cabbage dumplings. For the second course, the couple served deep-fried crispy egg noodles accompanied by 58-day-aged côtes de boeuf topped with a black pepper sauce, and the evening closed with a tea ceremony complete with bright blue, pebble-shaped baos filled with cherries and molten chocolate or red bean paste and white chocolate. When turned over, each bun revealed the outline of a face that was smiley, sad or pouty. At the link in our bio, the pair share their tips on throwing a festive dinner of your own. Written by Sophie Bew, photo by Tami Aftab. #TSummerEntertaining

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by T: The NYTimes Style Magazine on July 26, 2021 tagging @salie66. May be an image of 3 people, people standing and indoor.

node.text: When the art dealer James Shalom first visited a Neoclassical townhouse on Manhattan’s Upper East Side nearly two years ago, he had no idea that the sweeping space would become the headquarters of his very own clothing line. “Fashion was completely new to me,” recalls Shalom. But he had an eye for fabric and fit, and he and his father, Elliot, a wholesale manufacturer, set to work constructing their dream uniform of simple silhouettes expertly crafted by a handful of small family-run mills and factories in the Bassano del Grappa region of northern Italy. “We were on Zoom with them every day, refining each piece,” Shalom says of the carefully considered men’s and women’s wardrobe essentials that now make up his new label, @Salie66, named for his mother. As he puts it, “We wanted to create clothes that you could wear every single day — throughout the seasons and the years — and not have to think too much about it.” Click the link in our bio for more. Written by @ZoeRuffner, photo by Zhi Wei. #TList

user.full_name: R E S C H I O - Estate & Hotel

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by T: The NYTimes Style Magazine on July 26, 2021 tagging @reschio, and @bbforreschio. May be an image of indoor.

node.text: #RoomOfTheDay: Effortless Italian style has become the hallmark of Hotel Castello di Reschio (@reschio), which is located in the wild Umbrian countryside. The tower suite, which spans multiple floors, features an original stone-carved fireplace, locally-sourced antique furniture and lighting from the architect-hotelier Benedikt Bolza’s furniture line, @BBforReschio.
